article: One day, an expert in time-management was speaking to a group of business students. To make the point  _  , he used an illustration. As he stood in front of the group, he said, "Okay, time for a quiz." He then pulled out a wide-mouth jar and set it on the table. Then he  _  placed about a dozen fist-sized rocks, one by one, into the jar. When the jar was filled to the  _  and no more rocks would fit inside, he asked, "Is this jar  _  ?" Everyone in the class said, "Yes." "Really?" Then he  _  under the table and pulled out a bucket of gravel(,),dumped some in and  _  the jar, causing pieces of gravel to work themselves down into the space  _  the big rocks. Then he asked the group the same question. "Probably not." One of them answered. "Good!" he replied. He reached under the table and  brought out  a bucket of sand. He started dumping the sand in the jar and it went into all the  _  left between the rocks and the gravel.  Once more  he asked the question. "No!" the class shouted. "Good!" Then he grabbed a can of water and began to pour it in  _  the jar was filled to the brim. Then the expert in time-management looked at the class and asked, "What is the  _  of this illustration?" It is such a seemingly easy question that one  _  student raised his hand and said, "It is, however full your schedule is, if you try really hard you can always  _  some more things in it." "No," the speaker replied, "The truth it teaches us is that you will  _  get them in at all if you don't put the big rocks in first.  _  the big rocks in your life are, do things that you love and  _  for yourself. In your schedule if you value the little stuff then you'll fill your life with  _  things and you will never have the real quality time you need to spend on the big, important stuff. So, tonight, or in the morning, when you are  _  on this short story, ask yourself what are the 'big rocks' in your life? Then put those in your  _  first."
